flashcards.definition: The study of the nature of reality, existence, and fundamental questions about the universe.
A branch of metaphysics concerned with the study of being and existence.
The view that everything that exists is physical or material in nature.
The belief that reality consists of two fundamental substances, such as mind and body.
The philosophical issue concerning the relationship between consciousness (the mind) and the physical body.
René Descartes' view that the mind and body are separate substances that interact with each other.
The view that mental properties arise from physical properties but are not reducible to them.
The theory that mental states are identical to physical brain states.
The view that mental states are simply dispositions to behave in certain ways.
The theory that mental states do not cause physical events but are instead byproducts of physical processes.
The theory that mental states are defined by their functional roles rather than their physical makeup.
The belief that mental states like beliefs and desires do not actually exist and will be eliminated as science progresses.
The idea that complex phenomena, such as the mind, can be fully explained by simpler physical processes.
Philosopher known for substance dualism and the famous phrase 'I think, therefore I am.'
The argument that the mind and body are distinct because we can doubt the existence of our body but not our mind.
A challenge to dualism: how can a nonphysical mind interact with a physical body?
The idea that the mind and body do not interact but are instead synchronized like two clocks.
The view that God intervenes to coordinate interactions between the mind and body.
The belief that mental activities are purely physical processes occurring in the brain.
The idea that mental states are strictly identical to brain states.
A thought experiment suggesting that a physically identical being could lack consciousness, challenging materialism.

flashcards.term: Thomas Nagel’s 'What Is It Like to Be a Bat?'
flashcards.definition: An argument against materialism stating that subjective experience cannot be fully explained by physical processes.
A modern take on dualism that emphasizes the distinct properties of consciousness rather than substances.
The idea that mental states can be understood as computational processes similar to those in computers.
A test to determine whether a machine can exhibit intelligent behavior indistinguishable from that of a human.
An argument against strong AI, claiming that a machine can process information without truly understanding it.
Strong AI posits that a properly programmed computer has a mind, while Weak AI sees AI as a tool for simulating intelligence.
A critique of functionalism suggesting that a system with functional organization might still lack consciousness.
A thought experiment arguing against functionalism by suggesting that a system could have the right functional structure without genuine consciousness.
The subjective, first-person experiences that some argue cannot be explained by physical processes alone.
David Chalmers’ argument that explaining subjective experience is fundamentally different from explaining cognitive functions.
The theory that consciousness is a fundamental feature of all matter in the universe.
The idea that consciousness emerges from complex physical processes but is not reducible to them.
The belief that free will and determinism are compatible concepts.
The view that humans have free will and that our actions are not determined by prior causes.
